Award.AwardTitle: The International Mind, Brain, and Education Society (IMBES) Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The International Mind, Brain, and Education Society (IMBES) conference aims to facilitate cross-cultural collaboration across the cognitive, educational, developmental and neural sciences. The biennial IMBES meeting is a unique opportunity for scholars and educators to come together to engage in reciprocal dialogue about research and practice. Researchers investigating learning processes have the opportunity to share the results of their work with educators and receive feedback on the translational opportunities for the research. In turn, educators can update their understanding of the cognitive, developmental and neural bases of learning and share their knowledge of efficacious techniques, tools, and classroom practices with researchers. IMBES has now formed a partnership with the EARLI SIG 22, and they plan to meet jointly in 2021 and in 2022. <br/><br/>As a leading venue for building the science of learning, the 2021 IMBES conference includes the following objectives: (1) To build diversity in the attendees with travel fellowship; (2) To build diversity with a symposium addressing diversity in the science of learning; (3) To facilitate formation of a Global Science of Learning Network with travel fellowships to attend a pre-conference meeting. Conference abstracts and poster presentations will be available on the IMBES website (www.imbes.org) after the conference and selected papers will invited from the conference for peer review for possible publication in a special issue of the societyâ€™s journal, Mind, Brain and Education. To the extent possible, key sessions at the conference will be live-streamed and/or video-recorded for audiences who are unable to attend, including classroom teachers, educational administrators and policymakers.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bringing together researchers, educators, policy makers and students, the IMBES Conference aimed to bridge the gap between research and practice in the field of education. Providing opportunities for the sharing of best practices and updating understanding of the neural bases of learning, the IMBES Conference had an agenda that encouraged cross-talk between researchers and educators, a key component when it comes to translating findings from the research setting to the classroom and vice versa. The major goal of the project was to increase the attendance at the conference by generating interest in the conference proceedings and, ultimately, in the field of mind, brain and education.

The original plans for the IMBES meeting in 2020 and for using the NSF funds were iteratively revised to address the delays and challenges of the COVID pandemic.

Our first decision was to hold the central portions of the 2020 program as a series of virtual presentations over the summer of 2021. The series spanned two months and included seven presentations from various award winners who were planning on presenting at the canceled 2020 conference. These award winners included Dr. Mary Helen Immordino, Dr. Paige Harden, Dr. Elena Grigorenko, Dr. Michael Skeide, Dr. John Gabrieli, Dr. Niko Steinbeis, Dr. Kimberly Noble, Dr. Melina Uncapher, and Dr. Courtney Pollack. Each of the seven sessions included a range of 40-130 attendees and active question and answer discussions. All of the sessions are available on the IMBES youtube channel. We also included trainee research pitch presentations to highlight IMBES trainee research among the seven sessions. Research pitches were brief, five-minute videos of completed or in-progress research conducted by trainees in our community. The trainee then participated in the virtual conference series to participate in the active question and answer discussions. Attendance was free. The 2021 IMBES virtual conference allowed society members, both trainees and established, to reconnect after an uncertain and challenging year. The NSF grant covered the costs of putting on this free virtual program and archiving it.

Our second session was to plan a new program for 2022. The meeting remained in Montreal to fulfill our hotel contract. The full program is available at https://imbes.org/resources/IMBESConferenceProgram_2022_FA.pdf 

With NSF support, we were able to offer travel support, up to $2,000 per person. We gave awards to 11 conference attendees using this grant, 44 in total using other funds.

Overall, the conference attendees came from 16 countries: Austria, Belgium, Canada, Chile, France, Germany, Israel, Japan, Netherlands, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Switzerland, Taiwan, United Kingdom, United States. NSF sent Lori Takeuchi who was able to speak to attendees about NSF programs and opportunities.
